 ISLAMIC FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF THE COMOROS THIRD EDUCATION PROJECT CREDIT AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Islamic Federal Republic of the Comoros Beneficiary: Ministry of Education Targeted Intervention: Yes Credit Amount: Interim Trust Fund Credit of SDR 5.1 million (US$ 7.0 million equivalent) Terms: Standard IDA terms, with 1 0-year grace period and 40 years to maturity Commitment Fee: 0.50% on undisbursed credit balance, beginning 60 days after signing, less any waiver Project Description: The project would support investments in the first two priority sub-sectors identified in the Government's Program for the Reinforcement of Education and Training, namely primary education and vocational training. To ensure effective and timely implementation of the project, it would also support local capacity building in the planning, execution, monitoring and evaluation of sector management. The project would improve learning at primary level through increased participation in quality education. Participation would be improved through: (a) establishment of local school committees with financial and managerial authority on public primary schools; and (b) provision of adequate infrastructure through improvement grants to participating communities in targeted areas. Quality of the teaching-learning processes would be improved through: (a) development of better management practices to monitor delivery of the study program; (b) provision of teaching/learning materials, both for class and individual learning activities; (c) changes in the teaching-learning methods used by teachers in the classroom; (d) changes in the supervision practices to develop and monitor implementation of effective teaching practices; and (e) support to development
 Comoros: Third Education Project of learning assessment and education information systems at regional and central levels of the MOE. The project would improve competencies of skilled workers through the establishment of an autonomous, flexible and effective demand-driven training system in which training institutions and employers will get grants from the Government. The establishment of a performing vocational training system would be achieved through the creation of a small, autonomous institution -- the Office for Vocational Training (OVT) -- managed by an independent council. Competencies and skills would be developed through (a) support for management and the initial financing of a Vocational Training Fund (VTF) which would finance one part of the expenses of training linked to the execution of sub-projects which respond to needs identified in the labor market; (b) support for the development of training modules which lead to a qualification and the training of the trainers; and (c) support for the reorganization of existing vocational training institutions in order to develop autonomous management, as well as modular programs adapted to the labor market. The project would support the development of effective project management capacities among staff in the Project Management Unit (PMU) and improve competencies of MOE authorities in planning, execution, monitoring and evaluation of the sector program. INTRODUCTION 1.1 With GDP per capita estimated at US$460 (1996), the majority of the population of the Comoros (504,000 in 1996) lives in relative or near-poverty. On the other hand, the country has a favorable income distribution, with very few people at the extremes of wealth or poverty, a functioning traditional safety net which is supported through remittances from abroad (estimated at US$40 per year, per capita) and communities which have demonstrated cohesiveness, interest in the development process, willingness to pay for quality services, and ability to take responsibility for management. The 1994 Poverty Assessment I concluded that major improvements in poverty reduction had to come through: (a) overall economic growth, with equity; and (b) improved public services to the poor, especially primary education and primary health care. 1.2 These recommendations are fully consistent with the Government's long-term strategy --supported by the Bank-- to accelerate growth through increasing productivity in agriculture and developing the small-scale and informal sectors, while expanding into new areas such as tourism, export processing and financial and other business services. Of these areas, agricultural growth as well as small scale manufacturing and services will benefit the poor, provided access to relevant training programs is improved. In the social sectors, the priority is to improve the accessibility of basic services by attracting clients through the quality and reliability of health and education. This in turn calls for a well- balanced program of expenditures in these core sectors. This approach is in line with the Mini-CAS (June 1995) which recommends continued assistance to macro-economic and structural reforms initiated in the early 1990's through a proposed structural adjustment credit, and support to sectoral operations in the Agriculture / Environment and Education sectors. These proposed operations would complement the on-going FY92 Road Maintenance, the FY94 Small Enterprise Development, the FY94 Population and Human Resources Development (PHRD) and the FY97 Pilot Agricultural Services projects. 1.3 The Government is aware that the present education system is not producing the basic skills required for national development and the reduction of poverty. Following the democratization process initiated in the early 1990's, the Government of the Comoros held a National Conference in 1992, which was followed by the National Consultation on The World Bank (September 1994). B. ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT 1.4 Since independence in 1975 the country has experienced considerable economic change in trying to adjust its economy to the external environment. Following a decade of growth bubble generated by externally-financed infrastructure projects, real GDP slowed significantly from an annual average of 6 percent in the early 1980's to 0.6 percent over 1985-1995. This led to a decline in real per capita income by an annual average of about 2 percent during the past decade, and the emergence of chronic financial problems in the late 1980's. The decline in economic performance is a manifestation of the country's developmental constraints, which include a narrow export base, weak institutional capacity exacerbated by poor economic management, as well as an unfavorable private sector environment. To address its macroeconomic imbalances and remove some of the structural constraints to growth, the government launched an adjustment program in 1991. 1.5 The Adjustment Program. The adjustment program made progress in liberalizing imports and removing price controls on several commodities. It also improved the environment for private sector activity and made some progress in reducing the fiscal burden arising from the parastatal sector. These led to major improvements in budgetary as well as external current account deficits in 1992-93. During that period, there was also a strong economic recovery, accounted for mainly by the improved performance of agriculture, manufacturing and tourism. 1.6 In January 1994, the Comorian Franc (CF) was devalued by 33 percent in foreign currency, in concert with the 50 percent devaluation that was effected by other CFA countries. The economy's response to this devaluation was mixed. Slow down of economic activities in trade and agriculture was responsible for a real GDP decline averaging 2.3 percent a year in 1994-95. Tourism growth had some compensatory effect in 1994, with tourist arrivals registering a 20 percent increase, but this was dampened by the coup of September 1995. With major shortfalls in revenues and an increase in current expenditures, the country's fiscal performance in 1994 and 1995 was weak. By end of 1995, salary arrears for civil servants accumulated up to six months -- and reached 9 months by end of 1996 -- and external arrears reached US$43 million. The inflation rate rose by some 20 percent in 1994 but stabilized at about 7 percent in 1995. In 1996, real GDP grew by 1 percent as tourism picked up and the private sector started to regain confidence after the March presidential election, and the rate of inflation dripped to 3.5 percent as prices stabilized. However, public finances remain difficult. 1.7 Economic reforms in the Comoros have been complicated by the parallel efforts at introducing political reforms. The country's political landscape has been historically characterized by turbulence associated with attempts to reconcile modem governance with ancestral traditions. The latest phase of political change was initiated in 1990 with reforms aimed at bringing the country from one party rule to representative government. A multiparty Constitution was approved by referendum in June 1992. Since that time, however, the political situation has remained fragile, given the recent history of frequent changes in government and several coup attempts. 1.8 Presidential and legislative elections held in March and December 1996, respectively, represent a major landmark in the country's political transition process, and it is anticipated that this would usher in a period of stability. New private investments are forthcoming in the hotel expansion, fishing and manufacturing industry. The new Government has recognized the need for the country to improve its economic management and performance, and has started to take measures to improve budgetary revenues and cut expenditures. The devaluation of January 1994 has brought some improvement in the country's competitiveness, and continued membership of the Comoros in the Franc zone will provide a degree of stability based on prudent monetary policy. However, internal adjustment needs to be continued through compression of public expenditures and of the real cost of services and labor. The deepening of tax reforms is also needed to remove tax-induced distortions and strengthen government revenue base. The new Government is preparing a second adjustment program to support these reforms as well as consolidate the gains from the earlier adjustment efforts, and has requested support from the Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). A Structural Adjustment Credit and an IMF Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) are being prepared for Board consideration in the first half of FY98. C. RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN EDUCATION AND TRAINING 1.9 Modeled after the French system, the education and training system in the Comoros is structured around four levels delivered in corresponding types of school. These are: primary (grades I - 6) in primary schools; lower secondary (7 - 10) in collges; upper secondary (11 - 13) in lyc&es; and post-secondary (13 and above) in teacher, technical and management training institutes. In addition, a large proportion of children attend the coranic school, while modem pre-schooling is rudimentary (only 6
 4 kindergarten were registered in 1995) and mostly concentrated in the capital (Moroni). Like in most African countries, the demographic structure of the population represents a major burden on public finance with about 20 percent of the total population attending school and growing at approximately 2,7 percent per year. Starting from a very low base in the mid-1980's, private education witnessed a rapid expansion in recent years, especially at secondary level. 1.10 The Government is aware that the present education system is not producing the basic skills required for national development and the reduction of poverty. More than one-third of school-age children do not attend formal schooling at primary level and, among those who complete the 6-year primary cycle, only about 40 percent continue to lower secondary schooling. In 1995-96, net enrollment ratios (the latter take out over- and under-age children and repeaters) at primary and lower and upper secondary levels were estimated at 55, 9 and 2 percent, respectively. Girls represented nearly 45 percent of enrollees at each level. However, these figures mask an inequitable distribution of services between the three islands. In 1995-96, girl's enrollment ratios were significantly lower than those of boys in 9 of the 15 school districts, especially in Anjouan. Access to primary education is constrained by limited space in existing classrooms. The vast majority of the 262 public primary schools (1996) were built more than 15 years ago, using space norms (less than 30 m2 per classroom) that are not adequate for the current size of classes (national average of 39 pupils) and site planning which does not provide for sanitary facilities and a minimum size courtyard. At secondary level, the capacity of the existing public colleges (41) and lycees (9) is underutilized, mainly due to restricted entrance at lower secondary level and recent expansion of private education, and MOE has already started rationalizing the school map with the closing of 5 collges and I lycees in 1994. 1.11 In addition, low internal efficiency and quality limit participation in education. Low internal efficiency is reflected by the gap between net and gross enrollment ratios at primary, lower and upper secondary levels, the latter estimated at 83, 26 and 15 percent, respectively by level. A cohort analysis shows that, allowing for a maximum of three repetitions, for 1,000 children entering Grade 1, only 174 are expected to enter the lower secondary cycle, 87 the lower secondary cycle and 25 to pass the Grade 13 examination (baccalaureat). The system must provide 14 years of schooling per student who completes the primary cycle. This situation is due in large part to the poor level of quality of public education. During the period 1991-1994, sporadic teacher strikes have also shortened dramatically the number of effective school days in the last four years to less than 100 days, compared with the stated norm of 160 school days per academic year. In 1994-95, at least 20 percent of public primary classrooms have been closed for lack of teachers. Shortages of school materials and poor management also contributed to the deterioration of quality. In reaction to deteriorating conditions in public schools, a growing number of parents and local authorities, mostly in the largest villages and in dynamic communities, chose private for-profit schooling. In 1995-96, enrollments in private schools continued increasing, representing 10 percent at primary, 39 percent at lower secondary and 32 percent at upper secondary levels (compared to 4, 22 and 9 percent in 1993-94). This shows an increasing demand and willingness to pay for private secondary education. While this development of private schooling is welcomed, it raises issues of equity, sustainability (e.g. if public schools resume normal operations) and quality assurance. Moreover, during the last two years, this development led to further deterioration of public education, especially for the poor. Teaching staff in private schools are recruited among civil servants who retain their public position but often neglect their obligations to public schools. The Government is moving prudently, considering a range of policies and measures to encourage development of quality private schooling, while at the same time improving equitable access to quality education and improving efficiency of public provision of education services. Measures that are being considered include: improved accreditation system for private schools, better control of teacher assignments and presence in public schools, and cost recovery for publicly- provided services to private schools (e.g. teacher in-service training, standardized examinations). 1.13 Unemployment, underemployment and low productivity are features of poverty in the Comoros as in many developing countries. In the Comoros, the main factor perpetuating poverty across generations is the low level of education among the poor which limits their employment and trade options as well as their mobility. In addition, relatively high wages (in foreign country terms) and low productivity contribute to poverty by making the Comoros uncompetitive in international markets. 1.14 The labor market in the Comoros is not well known. The last comprehensive manpower survey was conducted in the early 1980's; it has not been updated since, thus making it difficult to assess the changing needs of the labor market, particularly in the areas of tourism, commerce and trade, and the informal sector. The 1991 population census indicates that the formal sector is small with about 21,000 employees in services, 6,000 public civil servants and 1,000 employees in private manufacturing. These institutions are under the Ministries of Education (ENTP - Ecole Nationale Technique et Professionnelle; ENAC - Ecole Nationale d'Administration et de Comptabilite; and the CNH - Centre National Horticole), Agriculture (ENA - Ecole Nationale d'Agriculture; ENP - Ecole Nationale des Peches), and Health (ENS - Ecole Nationale de Sante). The latter three closed in recent years after having trained technicians and skilled workers who were employed mostly in government agencies. The Second Education Project assisted in the creation of ENTP and ENAC and financed civil works, equipment and development costs. Technical assistance was provided under the French and Belgian bilateral assistance programs. Private provision of training started only recently and is still embryonic. Also, community-supported apprenticeship schemes have been initiated and are supported by the Community Development Fund (FADC) supported under the IDA-financed PHRD Project. 1.16 The main issues of the current vocational training system are: (a) inadequate training programs that serve poorly the needs of the labor market; (b) the absence of reliable information on labor market to guide decisions on training strategies and programs; (c) poor quality of training due to low levels of qualification of instructors and insufficient financial resources; (d) the absence of the private sector in the planning, management and financing of training; and (e) high costs of training due to inefficient use of resources. 1.17 Post-secondary education available in the Comoros consists of teacher training, agriculture, a business school and the school of health sciences, which overall provide about 400 student-places. Two teacher training institutions (IFERE or Institut de Formation et de Recherche en Education), one in Grande Comore and one in Anjouan (which was refurbished and equipped under the Second Education Project) offer pre- and in-service training to teachers at primary and lower secondary levels. A large number of students (estimated at about 1,000 in 1995) go abroad for university studies. Given its priorities and resource availability, the government has agreed with donors to limit the number of scholarships abroad to those provided by donor funds. D. FINANCING OF EDUCATION 1.18 Public financing of education in the Comoros compares favorably with Sub- Saharan Africa (SSA) countries. The share of public education expenditure in GDP averaged 4.0 percent in the early 1990's, slightly above SSA comparable countries, and private financing (both for- and not-for profit) accounted for an additional 25-35 percent of public expenditure. During the period 1991-1995, GDP grew by 1.3 percent p.a. on average while at the same time total public recurrent expenditure decreased by 6 percent p.a. as a result of government's effort to reduce public expenditure and control the deficit.
 7 Against this unfavorable economic situation, the share of public education expenditure was maintained at approximately 25 percent of total government spending, reflecting the sustained priority to the social sectors and to the education sector in particular. However, total public expenditure in the sector in 1994 (actual) and 1995 (budgeted) fell below the 1990 level in real terms. And since the share of salaries in total education expenditure was maintained, non-salary expenditures, especially on operating expenditure and consumables, were hard hit. The 1996 recurrent budget for education proposed a significant increase --12.5 percent in real terms compared to 1995-- raising the share of education in total public expenditure to 29.1 percent (26.1 percent in 1995). A significant part of that increase, however, was allocated to salaries to the detriment of materials and consumables. To protect "vital" non-salary expenditure the Government is envisaging fixed levels of budgetary resources to priority operations which would be monitored closely. Starting in 1995 the MOE budgeted a block transfer to schools for the opening of the 1995-96 academic year. During negotiations, agreements were reached on further measures to be introduced in 1997. These include provision of budgetary resources to ensure: (a) a minimum of two visits of the district Inspectorate to each primary school; (b) a minimum of 10 working days of in-service training per year, to be organized at the school and district levels; (c) a provision of at least 600 FC (US$1.70) per pupil, per annum, to purchase teaching-learning materials; and (d) two school census per academic year (November and June) to monitor the performance of the education and training system. 1.21 Salary Expenditure. Salaries represent nearly 80% of total public recurrent expenditure on education, comparable to most developing countries around the world. The current composition of these expenditures in the Comoros prevents further economies and/or reallocation of expenditure within the sector (from salary to non-salary) for two reasons. First, as a result of the Civil Service Reform initiated in 1991 under MERCAP, the total number of staff positions in MOE has been reviewed and determined after extensive studies and internal reorganizations. Thus, further reductions of salaries that could be generated from streamlining or downsizing are difficult. Second, an additional 100 teaching positions in public primary schools have remained vacant since mid-1996. This is due to delays in implementing staff reductions in other parts of government, which would have freed positions within the agreed upon ceiling and allowed the MOE to recruit teachers in accordance with its approved staffing plan. Thus, there is an urgent need to recruit additional teachers at primary level, which will increase the share of expenditure on salary in MOE over the total government budget for salary while at the same time complying with aggregate number of positions and total salary bill. 1.22 Effectiveness. Of all issues in the financing of education in the Comoros, the reduction of the wastage of public resources and poor management bears the most promising pay-off, but is also the most difficult to address. During the period 1991-1994, the public education system has been paralyzed by frequent strikes --called by teachers' unions as well as by other constituencies-- with the net effect to dispense less than 60% of the expected 160 days of schooling per academic year. This has had an immediate and profound impact on public finance, quality of schooling, learning outcomes of students,
 9 morale of staff in MOE and the level of public confidence on education. Since the Government kept paying salaries --albeit with delays from 2 to 6 months-- to civil servants on strike, approximately 40% of the salary bill has been wasted. Moreover, frequent, unexpected and uncontrolled strikes have left thousands of students with disrupted instruction and an absence of follow-up. In recent years, larger number of parents decided to send their children to private schools which multiplied rapidly in all parts of the country, especially at secondary level and in the capital. However, as noted above (para. 1.12), most of the new private schools recruited their teaching staff among qualified teachers in public schools, thus preventing exertion of pressure from teachers and parents to reach an agreement to the labor conflicts. 1.23 During the first half of 1995, the Government adopted a strong position vis-a-vis the unions, announcing that it would not pay salaries for a two-month strike in late 1994. That decision was reverted by the next Government in October 1995, in the wake of presidential elections. Other promising measures were also implemented before the September 1995 coup. They included participation of Government authorities in open public debates (organized by a private television network established in Moroni) to raise awareness and justify policies adopted by government. Also, representatives of teachers' unions were invited to participate, as full members, to steering committees in charge of preparing the 1995-96 academic year and of recruiting and training primary level teachers. In addition, the MOE initiated discussions with representatives of the private sector with the view to ensure that minimum requirements for public service are met by those teachers who cumulate teaching in public and private schools. 1.24 These measures point to the need for continued dialogue with the various partners to re-establish an ethos in the education sector. Promising strategies aim at: presenting the Government's policies in a clear, transparent and objective manner, through the media while at the same time inviting other partners to participate in the resolution of problems; encouraging participation of all stakeholders in the decision-making process at the level which is most appropriate for the resolution of the issue; setting clearly and disseminating widely the goals and objectives of the system in operational terms that can be measured and reported back regularly; and collecting and disseminating information on key financial and technical performance indicators. 1.25 Parficipation, Responsibility and Accountability. One of the merits of the extensive consultations which have taken place in the sector over the last 2 years is the recognition of the need to change the role of govermnent from a universal and unique provider of free education to one of partner with important, but limited resources. This is not new in the Comoros since local communities have been traditionally actively involved in the financing, management and operation of social services (para. 1.1). However, over the years parents and students got accustomed to stipends for teachers trainees and students at technical training institutions, free boarding for all students and unlimited number of years of fellowship for tertiary level education abroad. In recent years, measures have been implemented to cut back or eliminate these expensive and ineffective incentives: stipends to instructor trainees have been abolished in 1994;
 10 boarding facilities in secondary schools have been closed gradually over the last decade; and regulations have been introduced to limit the number of fellowships, identify priority areas of study and instigate students to complete diligently their study program. 1.26 Other measures and actions are needed. Their aim is to encourage participation of parents, local communities, private enterprises and the beneficiaries in the financing of education, especially at secondary and tertiary levels where public funds will continue to finance a large part of the costs for a limited number of individuals. Policies to promote shared responsibility and enhanced accountability include: establishment of local boards and decentralization of decisions to the local authorities; establishment and implementation of objective criteria for selection of students and award of fellowships at secondary and tertiary levels; and transparent accounting and financing systems with regular audit reports. THE GOVERNMENT'S PROGRAM FOR THE REINFORCEMENT OF EDUCATION AND TRAINING 1.27 The production of the Program for the Reinforcement of Education and Training (PRET) is the culmination of a process initiated by the Government in early 1994 and supported by the Bank under the Second Education Project (closed in October 1994) and a first advance under the Project Preparation Fund (PPF) (approved in January 1995), with complementary financing from a Japan PHRD Grant approved in June 1994. This process involved direct participation of about 200 representatives from Government, regional and local authorities, villages' notability (notables), parents, teachers and students, public and private enterprises, and national consultants. In addition, the MOE commissioned 11 studies conducted by more than 30 local consultants with assistance from 4 international consultants. 1.28 The Program presents a long term vision of the directions of change, and the investment priorities in the first phase (1997-2002) of a development program that spans over two decades (to the horizon 2015). The overall goal is in harmony with the development objectives of the Comoros: to improve the quality of life of the Comorians at the same time as giving priority to economic growth and to an equitable distribution of basic social services. This is to be achieved through closer and more cost-effective collaboration between schools and communities, as well as between training institutions and the labor market. During the first five-year period, priority would be given to improving access to quality basic education, developing a performing manpower training system and strengthening managerial capacity to lead, monitor, evaluate and sustain measures and actions outlined in the program. During the same period, low cost priority investments would be made to improve quality and efficiency of secondary, tertiary and pre-schooling education. 1.29 The program rests on two complementary strategies. First, the aim is to improve learning outcomes of students in their immediate environment, namely the classroom and the school they attend. Second, the aim is to empower village communities in the
 11 management of schools and those involved in economic activities in the design, implementation and evaluation of priority initiatives in training. 1.30 The choice of these strategies draws on economic, institutional and political analyses. In the economic plan, the priority sectors of basic education and manpower training are informed by analyses of the viability and of externalities which demonstrate their impact on improving the quality of life, especially for the poor. In the institutional plan, recent studies undertaken by MOE indicate the need, on the one hand, to lighten and to recenter the role of the federal state institutions and, on the other hand, to empower the primary beneficiaries (youth, their families, the village and employers) by means of contracts involving partnership and productivity. Finally, in the political plan, the strategy rests upon the principle of participation of local communities in education, which was enunciated as a consequence of the Etats Ggneraux of education and embodied in the PRET. 1.31 The PRET has been defined by the principal partners of the State: the Ministry of Education, the Ministries of Finance and of Planning, of Agriculture and of Production, as well as the Chamber of Commerce, economic and social partners, and employers. The major orientations of the program have equally formed the basis of consultations within Government and with international agencies such as UNDP, UNICEF, UNESCO, ISESCO, the French Cooperation, the European Union and CIDA. 1.32 The current version of the financial plan estimates that priority investments for the initial five-year period (1997-2002) total FC 12.0 billion (or US$34.0 million), including FC 3.5 billion from Government, FC 1.0 billion from local communities and FC 7.5 billion (or US$21 million) from the donor community. The share of investments by sub- sector would be aligned on the priorities, with primary education receiving more than 60%, vocational training 12-15%, institutional strengthening 10-12%, and secondary and tertiary education about 7-8% each. Although there has not yet been firm commitments by donors, an estimated FC 5.6 billion (or US$16.0 million) could be made available in the short- to medium-term. The last of a series of informal meetings took place in March 1997 with the participation of representatives from donors present in the Comoros, namely: UNDP, UNICEF, ISESCO, the European Union, the French Cooperation, China, India, the Islamic League and the African Muslim Agency. ECONOMIC JUSTIFICATION OF THE PROJECT 3.35 The economic analysis of the project includes: (a) an assessment of potential savings that would be generated from an improvement in internal efficiency at primary level; (b) an examination of equity issues including distribution of public spending on education, and geographic, gender and income disparities; (c) an analysis of the consistency of the education sector budget with the overall macroeconomic framework; and (d) an examination of the rationale for public intervention in vocational training and the rate of return associated with vocational training. 3.36 Internal Efficiency. In a context of severely constrained public resources, savings generated through improvement of internal efficiency can be substantial. Based on 1993-94 data, computation of student flows shows that it takes on average 4.9 times longer to produce a primary-school graduate in the Comoros than in a system with no repetition or dropouts. As a result of measures to be implemented during the project, it is expected that reductions in the drop-out and repetition rates would: (a) reduce the average number of student-years to produce a graduate from 29.6 to 8.1; (b) generate savings up to 350,000 FC per graduate; and (c) increase the number of children completing Grade 4 by 88 percent (or from 48 percent to 90 percent of the cohort completing Grade 4). 3.37 Equity. The Gini coefficient associated with the distribution of public spending on education is currently 0.46. Analysis shows that et ceteris paribus: (a) increasing primary enrollment ratio and (b) increasing unit spending in primary education would reduce the Gini coefficient significantly. For example, a one-point increase in primary enrollment ratio reduces the Gini coefficient by about 2 percent, while an increase in unit spending of 5,000 FC reduces the Gini coefficient by about 1.3 percent. The analysis has also permitted to identify underserved districts for targeted intervention, on the basis of gross and net enrollment ratios, new entrants in Grade 1 and gender disparities. 3.38 Sustainability. In terms of financial sustainability, the investments planned under this project will require that the Government undertake a series of measures to increase public revenues, to allocate sufficient levels of public resources to education, and to rationalize expenditures in the sector. During appraisal, agreement was reached on: (a)
 39 a sustainable Public Expenditure Program (both investment and recurrent) for the period 1997-1999; and (b) the level and composition of the recurrent budget for salary and non- salary expenditures. Proposals for alternative investment and recurrent budgets were discussed with Government in the context of a joint Bank/IMF mission that visited the Comoros in January/February 1997. These proposals are described in Section C of Annex 6. 3.39 Vocational Training. While there is a need for government to reassess its role as provider and principal financier of technical education, government intervention is still desirable for two reasons. First, there are acute coordination problems in the Comoros. Most enterprises are too small to individually incur the overhead costs of training programs, and since the cost of coordinating with other enterprises in the sector is high, the demand for training is likely to be sub-optimal. By acting as coordinator and facilitator, the Government can usefully contribute to the well-functioning training system. Second, there are externalities associated with some vocational training schemes that are not captured by the beneficiaries of the training. There is a risk that private demand for training be sub-optimal from a social viewpoint. The proposed Vocational Training Fund will discriminate between the different training schemes. In areas where there is a presumption that benefits are captured by the beneficiaries, the Fund's contribution will be limited to support government's role of facilitator and coordinator. In areas where there are large external benefits, the Fund might subsidize part of the training scheme. Thus, the Fund would be used as an instrument to modulate the form of government intervention and the extent of public financial involvement. Based on a quick survey conducted during project preparation, the rate of return of vocational training is estimated at 27 percent. 3.40 Consistency with CAS. The Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for the Comoros calls for: enhanced competitiveness for sustained growth; human capital development, poverty reduction, and population growth control; and protection of the environment. In the education sector, the CAS objectives are to: (a) protect real expenditures in the sector; (b) improve efficiency of staff through effective deployment and control at school level; and (c) improve participation in quality education, especially for girls, and upgrade competencies of workers in a changing environment (export-led and private-sector based economic development). 3.41 The CAS also supports broadening the support base for, and building of greater local ownership of development operations. The CAS proposes that the Third Education Project place greater management and financial responsibility and accountability at the school level than in the past.

B. RiSKS 4.2 There are three risks foreseen at this point. First, the recently appointed Government may not be committed to put the structural adjustment program back on track and provide appropriate level of public resources in the sector. The 1992-94 implementation record on structural reform indicates that a sound macro-economic framework can be worked out. In view of the fact that university primary enrollment is a declared objective of the GOC, it is appropriate that the freed-up resources be allocated to accommodate more children in the school system. The question then is how best to use these savings in order to increase enrollment; in other words, what are the most cost-effective ways of achieving this objective. The community-based approach retained in the GOC strategy and adopted in this project could indeed be the best instrument by which to determine what the most cost-effective investments are for each school if only because the stakeholders are given a real opportunity to analyze problems, prioritize corrective actions, mobilize staff, and change the school environment as appropriate. This heuristic process is more likely to yield the best mix of inputs and measures to correct a malfunctioning school than is a deterministic, top-down approach. The following additional elements militate in favor of the community-based approach: (i) by giving communities an opportunity to create and manage assets, their role in the education sector changes from that of consumers to that of stakeholders; (ii) stakeholders are informed of the financial and social cost implications of low efficiency and are therefore more concerned about dropout and repetition; and (iii) the system would be building upon an existing track record of strong communal ties and community involvement in the creation and management of assets.

I Public intervention in vocational training No general case can be made for public provision of vocational training, but a case can be made for public intervention in vocational training. There is little or no dispute as to the need to rationalize publicly-provided vocational training schools - the supply-driven approach that currently exists has proven to be a failure. The proposed change to a demand-driven system that is responsive to expressed needs is most urgent. While there is a need for Govemnment to give up on its role as provider and principal financier of technical education, there are reasons to believe that some forms of government intervention in the field is still desirable and necessary. The first reason is that there are acute coordination problems in the Comoros. Most enterprises are too small to individually incur the overhead costs of training programs, and since the cost of coordinating with other enterprises in the sector is high, the demand for training is likely to be sub-optimal. By acting as coordinator and facilitator, the Government can usefully contribute to the well-functioning training system. The second reason is that there are externalities associated with some vocational training schemes that are not captured by the beneficiaries of the training. Once again there is a risk that private demand for training be sub-optimal from a social viewpoint. The proposed Vocational Training Fund, which will be the principal instrument for furthering the new technical training policy, will have to discriminate between the different training schemes. In those areas where there is a presumption that benefits are captured by the beneficiaries, the Fund would restrict its intervention to that of facilitator and coordinator: fees paid by beneficiary firms and individuals will then have to cover the direct training costs. In areas where there are large external benefits, the Fund might subsidize part of the training scheme. According to its diagnostic of the particular distortion that is causing sub-optimal outcomes in the training market, the Fund is therefore able to modulate the form of its intervention as well as the extent of its financial involvement. doc.abstracts: The Third Education Project will support investments in the first two priority sub-sectors identified in the Government's program for the Reinforcement of Education and Training, namely primary education and vocational training. To ensure effective and timely implementation of the project, it will also support local capacity building in the planning, execution, monitoring and evaluation of sector management. The project will improve learning at primary level through increased participation in quality education. Participation will be improved through: (a) establishment of local school committees with financial and managerial authority on public primary schools; (b) provision of adequate infrastructure. Quality of the teaching-learning processes will be improved through: (a) development of better management practices to monitor delivery of the study program; (b) provision of teaching/learning materials, both for class and individual learning activities; (c) changes in the teaching/learning methods used by teachers in the classroom; (d) changes in the supervision practices to develop and monitor implementation of effective teaching practices; and (e) support to development of learning assessment and education information systems at regional and central levels of the Ministry of Education (MOE). The project will also improve competencies of skilled workers through the establishment of an autonomous, flexible and effective demand-driven training system in which training institutions and employers will get grants from the Government. The establishment of a performing vocational training system will be achieved through the creation of a small, autonomous institution: the Office of Vocational Training (OVT). Competencies and skills will be developed through: (a) support for management and the initial financing of a Vocational Training Fund (VTF); (b) support for the development of training modules; and (c) support for the reorganization of existing vocational training institutions. Finally, the project will support the development of effective project management capacities among staff in the Project Management Unit (PMU) and improve competencies of MOE authorities in planning, execution, monitoring and evaluation of the sector program.
